Award.AwardTitle: The Influences of Place in the Community Reintegration of Former Prisoners

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to understand how the process of desistance from crime is shaped by neighborhood context and residential change. First, in terms of context, evidence suggests that the removal and return of prisoners to and from communities undermines neighborhood stability, creates a demand on resources, contributes to fear of crime and negative affect towards the community, and contributes to ex-prisoner recidivism. In addition, communities may vary in the level of stigma they exhibit towards former prisoners. Second, residential change is a potentially key turning point in the life course of desisting offenders. Yet given economic and social constraints, former prisoners are unlikely to move to communities with adequate resources and they often move to areas with large numbers of former prisoners. While community context and residential change are linked to reoffending and desistance, the mechanisms of these effects are less well understood.

This project will utilize in depth interviews and participant observation to explore the mechanisms underlying neighborhood influences on former prisoner desistance. Data come from two sources: 1) Participant observation and interviews with residents and community leaders in three neighborhoods that are strategically chosen to represent variation in former prisoner concentration. 2) Repeated interviews with recently released prisoners; respondents will be interviewed once shortly before their release from prison and four times in the community. Male and female respondents will be recruited, with special attention to those who will be released to the three target communities. In addition, the research team will attempt to recruit a mix of those who are moving to a new neighborhood and those returning to a previous neighborhood.

Together, these data will provide valuable information to better understand the impact of community context and residential change on former prisoner desistance, how communities view and respond to returning prisoners, and how former prisoners understand and experience their neighborhood context. Findings may inform criminal justice policies and programs, such as those around release and parole supervision, to decrease recidivism and support desistance efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were to understand the processes of formerly incarcerated people reentering society and striving to cease involvement with the criminal justice system, and how these are shaped by neighborhood context and residential change. First, in terms of context, evidence suggests that the removal and return of prisoners to and from communities undermines neighborhood stability, creates a demand on resources, contributes to fear of crime and negative affect towards the community, and contributes to former prisoner reoffending, rearrest, or reincarceration. In addition, communities may vary in the level of stigma they exhibit towards former prisoners. Second, residential change is a potentially key moment of change in the lives of people who have been incarcerated. Yet given economic and social constraints, former prisoners are unlikely to move to communities with adequate resources and they often move to areas with large numbers of former prisoners. While community context and residential change are linked to reoffending and desistance, or stopping offending, the mechanisms of these effects are less well understood.

 

This project is based on in depth interviews and participant observation to explore the mechanisms underlying neighborhood influences on former prisoner desistance and reentry from incarceration. Data come from two primary sources: 1) Repeated interviews with recently released prisoners. Respondents were interviewed once shortly before their release from a county level correctional facility and up to four times in the community. We interviewed men and women. For those with at least one post release interview (40 men and 24 women), we tracked them for an average of 10.5 months (up to 28 months). 2) Participant observation and interviews with residents and community leaders in three neighborhoods that were strategically chosen to represent variation in former prisoner concentration. We interviewed 86 residents across three neighborhoods, with varying levels of crime and incarceration.

 

People being released from the correctional facility had varying relationships to their neighborhoods. At the time of the second interview (2-4 weeks post release), approximately a third of the interviewees were not staying where they expected. About half moved more than twice in the time that we followed them. Even among those who were fairly stably housed, some considered their situation fairly permanent while others considered it temporary, but were unable to secure permanent housing. Among those that were trying to avoid criminal activity and criminal justice system involvement, most tried to manage their movements, to avoid being in places where they may experience temptation, such as offending peers or access to drugs, or a heightened sense of surveillance. The fear of surveillance was particularly pronounced among young Black and Latino men, who regularly reported being told they “fit a description,” and others who were known to police as criminals or drug addicts. For some people who were stably housed, much of their time was spend in non-neighborhood spaces that were significant to them. In addition, about a third of the interviewees were extremely unstably housed, often moving across town every few days or weeks. Often this was tied to other forms of disadvantage, including weak ties to family members, often as a result of a protracted history of drug addiction. While neighborhood was important for some, these two patterns (the importance of non-neighborhood places and extreme residential instability) highlight the limitations of the ways in which we typically consider neighborhood in understanding reentry experiences.

 

From the perspective of other residents, both neighborhood context and a person’s relationship to their neighborhood shaped their perceptions of crime and incarceration. Those who lived in higher crime areas, but had stronger social ties in the neighborhood, felt fairly safe because of those ties. In all neighborhoods, newer residents relied on aesthetics and physical cues to determine the safety of their neighborhoods. Those living in neighborhoods with higher numbers of formerly incarcerated people were more likely to know someone who had been incarcerated and were therefore less fearful and more accepting of returning prisoners. In other areas, some were sympathetic and advocated for second chances for people they perceived to be homeless, addicted to drugs, or formerly incarcerated in the abstract, but were more hesitant to live near or rent to a returning prisoner.

 

Together, these data contribute to our understandings of the ways in which place matters in understanding incarceration and prisoner reentry. The project can contribute to policy, particularly in terms of housing policies that may increase the stability and improve outcomes of returning prisoners and to develop those policies with attention to allaying the concerns of other residents.
